results.title: As is
results.creator_credit: Iris Merlis, Brandman Productions, Interchange Television Group and Michael Lindsay-Hogg
results.brief_description: Based on a play by William M. Hoffman, this made for television feature length film was originally produced for Broadway by The Circle Repertory Company and The Glines. Reflective, confronting, compassionate, and experimental in treatment and language “As is” deals up-front with the issue of AIDS in its early days, documenting the different phases from all angles, from the victim through to the lover, the friends, the family and the health carers. Through a montage of scenes, multi-layered, past and present, we witness the story of Rich (Robert Carradine), a Manhattan-based writer who discovers he has a pre-AIDS condition, subsequently finding himself being ostracised by one and all. Alienated and surrounded by fear and paranoia Rich has to mentally come to terms with AIDS and the ignorance which exists amongst the general population, including the medical fraternity, about this new disease. His friend and ex-lover Saul (Jonathan Hadary) is there to support Rich through the emotional stages of fear, anger, denial, cynicism, death vs the will to live, and finally, acceptance. Colleen Dewhurst is outstanding as the hospice worker who through her monologues to the camera tells us what it’s like caring for AIDS patients, her emotional attachments and her anger and frustration with this disease called AIDS. Although acted and directed in a theatrical style, “As is” still is an exceptional film, informative and compassionate, and particularly interesting from an historical viewpoint. Cast also includes Joanna Miles, Allan Scarfe.

results.title: As good as it gets [Widescreen] [Captioned]
results.creator_credit: Tri-Star Pictures, Bridget Johnson, Kristi Zea and James L. Brooks
results.brief_description: Melvin (Jack Nicholson) has established a regimented lifestyle which enables him to cope with his obsessive-compulsive disorder. His routine existence is interrupted by changes in the lives of his neighbour Simon (Greg Kinnear), and his waitress Carol (Helen Hunt). Caring for Simon’s dog, and his involvement in Carol’s personal life puts him back in touch with a humanity which has been lacking in his structured life. Powerful performances from Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt, who both won Best Actor Oscars for their efforts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tri-Star Pictures, Bridget Johnson, Kristi Zea and James L. Brooks

results.title: As a matter of fact: a film about abortion
results.creator_credit: Women's Health Resources Foundation, Womens Film Fund, Creative Development Branch of Australian Film Commission, Susan Lambert and Robyn Dryen
results.brief_description: A documentary about a feminist run abortion clinic. Counselling is shown to be an important part of the procedure, which is carried out using local anaesthetic and the vacuum aspiration method. We follow one woman through the termination of her pregnancy, and other women tell why they chose to have an abortion. The film ends with an animated section on the struggle for free, legalised abortion in Australia and information on what to do and where to go if you are pregnant.
results.title_for_label: As a matter of fact: a film about abortion

results.title: ARTV
results.brief_description:
The Australian Centre for the Moving Image and SBS Independent will commission 16 artists to produce works for ARTV, an exhibition program which will be broadcast on SBS and shown on screens throughout ACMI concurrently, commencing on 8 June 2004.

ARTV is part of 2004, a survey exhibition of contemporary Australian visual culture presented by the Australian Centre for the Moving Image and the National Gallery of Victoria.

results.title: Arturo Toscanini
results.creator_credit: United Films and United States. Office of War Information
results.brief_description: Toscannini conducts the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a spirited rendition of Giuseppe Verdi’s “Hymn of the Nations”. With the Westminster Choir, featuring Jan Peerce as soloist, this performance was part of a celebration to mark the liberation of Italy during World War II. The film also sketches the life of Toscannini, showing the way in which he lived up to his convictions. No other credits available.
